2.4.23  1:27 pm   i wanted to ask a question and also share something with you

it seems that you did things by starting out with something you know you can do, like the early monday videos, and the early songs like "hi bye". i tried this, and i kinda liked doing it this way , but im so impatient and i keep wanting more more more more more, knowing i can't do much more - so instead ive been trying a different approach, which is the act like i'm a raytracing engine, where my first attempt is all encompassing, and grand in scope, but blurry and messy and noisy, and not good. then my second attempt is like a second pass, filling in some details, and making something less chaotic, and more understandable, then after many attempts, i start to fill in the holes and get the details down and make something better. have you ever at any point tried doing things this way?

     if i make the 1st thing grand and all-encompasing, ..... that's a recipe for forever. it would never get done. you said you were trying this. i'm curious to see if you've finished that first thing yet

      is there a name for that type of growth?


also i hope your work is going well! and i hope you are well, and i hope you are joyful today!

2.3.23  10:33 pm   if i wanted to improve my improvisation and/or songwriting, would it be useful to learn a new chord every day and see how it feels when played after/before/between/instead of other chords?

      no. i think doing this will trick you into becoming very uninspired, because a chord includes everything about how/when/where it was used, in the actual song or piece of music. And there's infinite hows/whens/wheres. and each of those things makes everything different about what the chord does. so what i'm saying is, you'll never be able to get a list of all those. So if you say you're gonna "learn a chord" every day, that implies that you're going to be getting them from some list, but there is no list. because it's infinite and there's no order. and some of them are the same, but all of them are the same and different from each other at the same time. Anyway, my point is, the only way to get chords is to either find them how they've already been used in music you know in love, or make them up entirely. so if you're doing it that way, then i think it could be cool.
      Anyway, for your situation i think i'd recommend 2 different things: 1 is songs/music. just study all the songs/music you actually know and love, and see what they're doing with chords. i think right now you might be expecting it to look like a shelf full of a cereal boxes, lined up like soldiers. but it's really not like that at all, and it's much more like a room full of furniture. that's the best way i can describe it. so if you're learning 1 "piece" of furniture per day, it's gonna be hard enough just to figure out what counts as 1 piece and what counts as 5. or what counts as just the space between the other furniture. anyway, i think you'll see what i mean once you dive into all your favorite songs.
      
      and there's another thing i would suggest, that's totally the opposite of studying songs. Just spend some separate time just going nuts on the instrument with a total blank canvas and no song or anything, total free time, next to an open window, and just let the demons fly right in. this is where you make up your own way of doing things. your own way of spending time, on the instrument. Just act like you're sitting in a giant barrel of untapped TIME. time to play any note, not play any note, or combination, for as long or not long as you can imagine. sometimes when doing this, using the pitch bend a little bit can be insanely helpful. just playing notes and tweaking the bend up and down by very small amounts while you play, can be an amazing way to cheat your way into that magic zone of actually feeling like you've just played exactly what you meant to play. and then that supercharges you into very quickly and genuinely discovering all kinds of relationships/intervals/shapes. maybe because it unearths the pitches just enough from their *absolute* location and then suddenly the relationships come alive and become way more potent. It's kind of like when you're eating a cake and you're not sure whether you're tasting the cake or just tasting the cake's location. then you move the cake 3 inches to the left and try the cake again, suddenly you have a more keen awareness of what the cake tastes like, regardless of its location

2.3.23  2:34 am   At the salmon part of Day Goes On are those just chromatic climbing dominant 13s? Like 7-3-13-R bottom up on each chord?

      not quite. the mid-range (non bass) is the same voicing all the way up (EXCEPT for the final downbeat which is different) and the bass is all over the place

2.3.23  2:10 am   bill i had a dream that was very similra to a memory from childhood (a good one) and all day ive been trying to remember that memory and its like 90% gone. I remember some places of that week, but aside from that I can't remember much. it's like at this point i miss remembering those things more than i miss those things, and it feels new and old at the same time? It's like I miss the idea of those memories more than the actual memories. in a sense it made me realize that i'll probably slowly start forgetting about today and closer days further in the future. Do you feel it too? Is art how you deal with that?

     just about

     is listening to music how you make this portals in the now to go back to in the future?

     that's one of the ways

      Is it okay to forget some good times if I dont forget that they were there?

     i think if you keep studying this you may find something quite alarming (or comforting, depenting on how you look at it): there's infinite times. infinite memories, infinite nostalgias, ...... we have them in dreams and don't remember most of them. there's infinite possible songs. this can be hard to cope with because the attachment to them can be so strong. and it doesn't mean you shouldn't get attached. please do get attached, and you can even compose new ones to share with others and get them attached. but be aware that there are infinite. which might seem like a hindrance to the attachment, but, it's really not. infinity is alarming but it's what the doctor ordered

      scramble to write down as much as you can immediately after waking up. and, over time, spend more time songwriting in general because that will increase your skills of writing things down, and, it will also increase the chances of getting more good ideas in your dreams
